ROBERT FIELD: Today, we're
going to start talking about polyatomic molecules.

And the easy thing to do
with polyatomic molecules is to let them
rotate because that's

a relatively small subject. And so I'm really
going to kill that.

OK, so the goal today is to
understand symmetric tops.

Wednesday, we'll talk
about asymmetric tops. And on Thursday, we'll
talk about transitions,

pure rotation transitions
in the general case.

OK, so first of all,
in a diatomic molecule, you have two atoms, and it
doesn't take much imagination

to think about a
coordinate system in which the diatomic molecule rotates.

You're going to rotate
about the center of mass. And it's not too hard
for a diatomic molecule

to figure out where the center
of mass is, and that's it.

And if the molecule
vibrates, the center of mass,

you're still-- you can still think of
where is the center of mass

during the vibration. And the vibration doesn't
do anything complicated.

It changes the
moment of inertia. And so you have to average
over the moment of inertia

to see how the rotational
constant changes with vibrational quantum
number, but there's nothing

terribly mysterious. The whole thing changes
as soon as you go away from the diatomic molecules.

So what we're going
to do is we're

going to derive the
rotational Hamiltonian for diatomic molecules.

And we'll show that it
has the form of Rx squared

over Ix plus Ry
squared over Iy or z

squared Iz, where these are
components of the rotation

angular momentum,
which we normally call J for diatomic molecules,
but for diatomics,

we call the rotation vector
R, and for polyatomics, when

we have vibrational-- when
we have angular momenta spin and orbital angular
momenta and vibrational angular

momenta, we'll add
those to make J. And so at least for now, I'm
going to just write this.

These are the
principal components of the inertial tensor.

And so most of what
we'll be doing today is discovering that,
yes, in fact, we

need to worry about a
inertial tensor, but we can

automatically--
we can diagonalize that thing and right the
Hamiltonian in this way.

So we'll derive this Hamiltonian
and then we'll simplify it.

So we'll figure out-- we'll
find the center of mass,

which is easy. But when you think
about a molecule vibrating, and
the center of mass

is going to have no definite-- I mean, the body frame
is determined entirely

by where the atoms are,
and the center of mass is not such a trivial concept.

Although, we'll not worry
about that too much.

OK, and then we'll talk
about rigid body motion.

And that will involve a
little bit of vector analysis. And we'll discover that we
can write the Hamiltonian

as some object like this,
where this is a tensor

quantity, which
relates the angular

momentum, the classical
angular momentum to--

yes, OK. So let's just begin. I'm very-- oh, I
forgot the erasers.

I'm very foggy today. And so I'm not going to be
able to do a very good job of leading through the algebra.

But I'm going to,
I think, still be able to tell you
what's important. OK, so we have a
polyatomic molecule.

And the first thing we need to
do is find the center of mass.

And it's always a
good thing, when

we're going between
quantum mechanics and classical mechanics,
which is what we're doing,

to use Cartesian coordinates. Because when you use
Cartesian coordinates,

you can always
symmetrize things. You don't get involved in
complicated hidden computation

problems. And so let's just worry
about the center of mass.

OK, so we have three
Cartesian coordinate equations

where we have the masses
and the coordinates of each.

So this is the
coordinate of each atom. This is the center of mass.

We're going to find
the center of mass. And the center of
mass enables you--

this equation enables you
to find the center of mass. These are three Cartesian
equations for x, y,
and z coordinates.  Let's think about ammonia.

Ammonia has enough
geometric complexity

to illustrate all
the key points. And so let's just draw
some simple-minded diagrams

for ammonia. OK, here is one simple-minded
diagram for ammonia.

We have a nitrogen with
its lone pair here. And we have three NH bonds.

We can also project
into a plane.

We know the angle between
the hydrogens is 120 degrees.

And we can use these
diagrams to calculate the Cartesian coordinates
of each of the atoms.

And we need the
Cartesian coordinates of each of the atoms
in order to calculate-- to locate the center of mass.

So we start with the coordinates
of the first hydrogen

in spherical polar coordinates
because that's easiest.

And so we can choose one
of the hydrogens to be--

we can choose this
hydrogen to be
in coincident with the z axis. Z axis-- no, I'm sorry.

So you can see what
you're in for today.
I'm really not here.

So the first hydrogen
is going to be

the one where the phi axis is-- the phi angle is 0. And so the bond
length is R. And so--

and now we want to convert that
to Cartesian coordinates, x1,

So we have this
angle down from the--
that's not what I want.
So here's the z axis. Here is H1. And this angle is theta.

And so once we do that,
we know the x and y
coordinates for that atom.
And so we have our sign, theta. Our cosine, theta.
And-- whoops.

AUDIENCE: So we're actually
getting the x z coordinate?

ROBERT FIELD: OK, so
yes, so this is x and z.

And what does it
say in the notes? X and z, right? And so we can do that thing
for each of the hydrogen atoms.

And we can start
with the nitrogen, at 0, 0, 0, which
is what I should

have said at the beginning. OK, so we use these
equations in your notes.

I'm not going to write them
all down because I'm going to make a big mess of them.

And we can solve the z equation,
for the location of the center

of mass in the z direction. So that's 0 is equal to the
sum of all of the atoms, mass
of the atoms, zi minus zcm.

And so we started out
with the nitrogen at 0.

And so all we have is 3 times
the mass of the hydrogen times
R cos theta minus zcm.

OK, and so we can solve for
the center of the z coordinate at the center of mass, simply
by rearranging this equation.

And we have 3 mh over 3
mh plus mn r cos theta.

This is just a total mess. I'm embarrassed to
be actually wasting

your time with this derivation. But I want to write on the board
over here where I cannot not
obscure it.

The center-- the
position of the hydrogens

in the center of mass
coordinate system are R sine theta 0 R
cos theta and n over m.

So this is the first step. And whether you-- I mean, I didn't teach
you how to do this.

You can do this
better than I can. Whenever you have
a molecule that you

want to look at
rotation, you figure out what the coordinates are
in the center of mass.

Then you do it in
Cartesian coordinates. OK.
And you're going to use that. OK, now we're interested--

we always start out with
classical mechanics. And we're interested
in what will be the Hamiltonian for rotation.

And the Hamiltonian for rotation
will be a kinetic energy term plus a potential energy term.
Molecule is free. So this is 0.

OK, the kinetic energy, the
rotational kinetic energy, is going to be--

well, kinetic energy is
always 1/2 mi vi squared.

Now the trick is to go
from linear velocities

to angular velocities. And so now we have a little
bit of vector analysis.

So here is the vector omega,
which is the angular velocity.

And the angular velocity
is about an axis. And so we have an axis here.

And the length of this
vector is the magnitude of the angular velocity.

Now, suppose we
have a particle, qi.
And it has mass mi.

And what we'd like--
what we need to do is to work out what is the
angle of this coordinate

relative to this? And so we want qi
perpendicular And qi parallel.

Where we want the
projection of q parallel to omega and the
projection of q perpendicular.

And if we can do that, we're
interested in that angle.

We can calculate
what the angle is and we can get all
the good stuff.
OK, so qi parallel.

Well, if you want something
that's parallel to--

you calculate qi
dot omega, right?

That's the projection. And cosine theta-- and
what am I doing here?
This is correct. I'm just jumping ahead.

Qi dot omega over
magnitude omega

is how you calculate a
component of a vector parallel to another vector.

And this is qi omega i
cos theta over omega i.

OK, and to get qi
perpendicular, well,

instead of using a
dot product, you're going to use a cross product. And so for this diagram--

where is it? Where is my diagram? Oh, here. So for this diagram here,
if we want qi cross omega--

so we use the right hand rule. And so we have qi
and we have omega.

And it says that the
direction is out of the plane.

And omega corresponds
to a rotation like this.

And so the cross product
is pointing that way.

We know the velocity
is this way. So we have a minus side.
So the i is minus qi dot omega--

cross omega. OK, so vi is qi
omega sine theta.

And so now we know the
magnitudes of q and omega.

And so we have a sufficient
amount of information

to calculate the velocity. Vi squared is going to be the
vi parallel squared plus vi--
I'm sorry.

So we do this. And we get qi omega squared
minus qi dot omega squared.

Whether you followed
my derivation or not--

I wouldn't have been able
to follow it-- this is--

qi squared omega squared. This is the actual
linear velocity.

And this gives rise to all
of the critical complexities
that we have to deal with. When we put in--

so when we calculate the
classical kinetic energy, 1/2 mi vi squared
sum over i, this

is where we get the
new thing, the thing that diatomic
molecules can't do.

We get the rotational
Hamiltonian is 1/2 sum over I
mi times xi squared

plus yi squared plus zi squared
omega z squared plus omega

y squared plus omega z
squared minus a whole bunch

of other stuff, xi omega x
plus yi omega i plus zi omega z

squared.  So this is a
horrible expression.

And a little algebra
simplifies it to the form
that we almost begin to like. We have sum of i, mi.

And now we have xi squared
plus yi squared w omega z

squared plus xi squared zi
squared omega x squared plus

yi squared zi squared
omega x squared

minus a whole bunch
of other stuff. Notice these are-- this gives
the square of the direction,

perpendicular to the z axis. This gives the square
of the distance

along the perpendicular
to the x axis. These are things that
we'd like to go away.

And these are called
moments of inertia.

These are called
products of inertia. And so if we write
the vector omega

and we write i as xx ixy ixz
xyy xzz and other stuff, where

x is m sum over i, and yi
squared plus zi squared.

So the xx moment of inertia
has the squares of the distance

perpendicular to x. And ixy is defined
as minus mi xyi.
Right.

So we have this thing. And the rotational Hamiltonian
has the form 1/2 omega i omega.

So this is just the
transpose of this. This is this tensor.

And this is this thing again. This gives, in a
compact form, what
the rotational Hamiltonian is.

This is a real symmetric matrix. It's always possible to
find a transformation that

converts this thing
to a diagonal matrix.

So we have written a
classical Hamiltonian

in compact, elegant form. We have an item inside it,
this moment of inertia tensor.

It's a symmetric matrix. That means we can find a
unitary that diagonalizes it.

And that means that we can
rewrite the Hamiltonian
in this convenient form.
OK, so we've just taken-- we have a unitary matrix.

And t dagger is the inverse
of the unitary matrix. So this is just 1.

And so I have now
written the quantities

we are really interested in. This is the diagonal matrix. And these are the
things that are

the components of the
angular [INAUDIBLE] in the reference frame where
we have an inertial tensor.

So what have we done? We've we found a
geometric transformation that diagonalizes this thing.

This just means we've chosen
a new xyz coordinate system

in order to define
our angular momentum. So these are the
angular velocities

in that special
coordinate system.

So what we call these things,
t dagger omega is just
omega a, omega b, omega c.

I should have written-- so these are the
angular velocities

about the a axis, the b axis,
and the c axis, three axes-- three orthogonal axes
in the coordinate system

that has the
convenient property, that this is diagonally.

OK, so back to problems
that you'd be interested in.

We're interested in finding
not the full inertial tensor.

We're interested in finding
the components ia, ib, and ic.

Now, for a general
problem, you have

to just [INAUDIBLE] that thing. You just choose a
coordinate system. And you ask your computer
to find the eigenvectors

and eigenvalues. And there you have it. But for most small
molecules, which

is what we're in
the business of, you can usually diagonalize
these things by inspection.

So if you have a molecule
which has some symmetry, the first thing you do is you
look for the highest order

rotation axis.  So if you have a c3 axis,
as you do in ammonia,

that's called the z axis.  And then you look
for a sigma v plane.

You're looking for
a plane of symmetry, which contains the z axis.

And if there's only one of
them, it's called the xz plane.

And so if-- sorry, this is
one of the symmetry axes.

Another is perpendicular
to the xz plane. That's the y axis.

And the third axis is
perpendicular to these two. So you find the highest
order rotation axis.

If it's c3, you're
pretty much guaranteed that you're going to
have a symmetric top.

If it's not c3, if it's
only c2, if there's still

a plane of symmetry as
there is in formaldehyde,

in c2v molecules, then
you have another-- you have another
uniquely-defined direction.

And you can then diagonalize
the inertial tensor by construction.

And that's convenient
because you don't have to do any
hard work and you can be looking at what's important.

OK, so you might
ask, well suppose

there is no sigma v plane, but
just a sigma v plane, as there is in the s1 state of settling.

Does that mean, you can
write the inertial tensor

in diagonal form by inspection? Well, let's look at
this for a second.
So we have the z axis like this. We have a reflection plane here.

And so that means that the
reflection plane doesn't help

us because we already found-- and so we know
that there's going

to be two axes in this
plane of the molecule. But we don't know
where they are.

So we have to
diagonalize it 2 by 2-- not a big deal.

OK, so I really wanted to
get through all of this

because now we get
back to the quantum mechanics and this
stuff that we know well.

You find the unique
coordinate system where the moment of
inertia tensor is diagonal.

And then we write
the Hamiltonian

for rotation in the
form 1/2 j [INAUDIBLE]

i minus 1 j because j
is equal to i omega.

And the kinetic energy is-- well, for linear momentum, t
is equal to p squared over 2m.

And so generalizing
to rotation, we're going to have j
squared over 2 omega--

j squared over 2i. OK, so this is the form of
the classical Hamiltonian

that we use to begin
doing quantum mechanics.
OK, so we have x, y, and z. And we have a, b, and c.

This is an important point. x, y, and z are defined
by symmetry elements.

a, b and c are defined by
the relative magnitudes

of the principal
components, ia, ib, ic.

We've diagonalized
the inertial tensor. And we have these three things. And by convention,
they are in this order.

AUDIENCE: How universally
is that convention? ROBERT FIELD: Absolute. AUDIENCE: OK. ROBERT FIELD: This is absolute. The x, y, z conventions
differ from one practitioner

to another. Usually, z is always this
symmetry, the highest order

axis. And x and y, depending
on who's doing it,

are sometimes reversed. And that has the
unpleasant effect

that we have-- in certain
groups, such as c2v,

we have symmetry species
a1 to a2, b1 to b2.

And the 1s and 2s
here are reversed--

very bad. And so it's always based on
which is x and which is y.

And there is
nothing overwhelming to force a universal agreement. So, of course,
people don't agree.

All right, but this is simple
because this is the smallest, this is the largest.

And it's always done this way,
as you will see in a moment. OK, so we can write
the Hamiltonian as j--

remember, this is
a diagonal matrix.

And these are three components. And so it's a trivial
thing to multiply out.

And we have ja squared over
ia plus jv squared over ib

plus jc squared over ic. OK, once we're at
this point, we're

going to want to somehow
be able to find out a way to use this basis set in
order to work out the matrix

elements of this Hamiltonian.  So there is a
clever little trick

that enables us to be able
to use this basis set. And this is the same basis set--

we use this basis set to
deal with symmetric as well as asymmetric tops.

OK, so we call a, the
a rotational constant,

h over c, 1 over
8 pi squared ia.
So this is just-- we get the--
I lost my 2s.

OK, so when we apply an
angular momentum operator

to an angular momentum function,
we get an h bar squared. We get an h bar
for each angular.

So we're going to get an h
bar squared when we apply. And so that's being
canceled by that.

We have a-- so we have a 4 pi
squared in the denominator. Another 2 is from the 1/2.

Then we have the ia. And this is just to put things
in reciprocal centimeter units.
OK, so we have a, b, and c.

So we can rewrite
this Hamiltonian. Now, in the standard form, we
have a tasteful Hamiltonian
as ja squared--

aja squared plus bjv
squared plus cjc squared.

OK, let us now consider
two special cases a prolate
and an oblate symmetric top.

A prolate top is like
this piece of chalk. It's got one small moment of
inertia about the long axis.

And if it's got a small
moment of inertia,

it has a large
rotational concept.

And then it has two
equal moments of inertia, like this and like that.

And we have an oblate top. And an oblate top
is like a Frisbee.

The symmetry axis of the
Frisbee is the c axis.

It's the heavy axis. And so we have c, which is the
unique, rotational constant.
It's the smallest one. And so we have these two limits.

And the beautiful thing
is when we have these two special limiting
cases, we can trivially

manipulate this thing into
a wonderful form where its--

again, its matrix
elements in the jkm basis can be taken automatically
without any thought,
OK, so let's look at this one. So we have a unique axis.

And we have two
that are the same. So let's just suppress
c for the time being

because it's really the same. OK, so we have--
now we have a, ja

squared plus b times jb
squared plus jc squared,

which is equal to j
squared minus ja squared. Done.

I love this because, you
know, you're wandering around. And you're wondering, how are
you going to deal with this?

And as soon as you
say I've chosen two of the rotational
constants to be equal,

everything simplifies. And so for the prolate top,
the rotational Hamiltonian

is a ja squared plus bj
squared minus ja squared.

Or bj squared plus a
minus b ja squared.

So j squared is the
angular momentum operator

that corresponds to
the j label in the jkm. And ja is just like what
we had four diatomics, jz.

And so this gives k squared. So we get jj plus 1 here,
then k squared here.

AUDIENCE: So it's almost
like an honorary diatomic?

ROBERT FIELD: That's right. And whether it's oblate or
prolate, it doesn't matter. It's just that
what we do is for--

so that's a prolate. And for an oblate,
we have bj squared
plus c minus b jc squared.
Again, k squared.

c minus b is negative. a minus b is positive. That's the whole--
that's the whole world.

I mean, so whether
it's oblate or prolate, we have two convenient limits.

The Hamiltonian
is really trivial, no off diagonal elements. We just get simple
energy level formulas.

You know, the only-- what's counter to it? Well, there's a lot
of work you have to do to figure out what
the moments of inertia

are and so on. But that's just
algebra and geometry.

Once you make this
wonderful simplification, which is only true for molecules
with a certain symmetry--

OK, so I haven't solved
the problem generally.

But I've created
a basic set that enables us to understand
both symmetric tops

and asymmetric tops. What time is it? OK. AUDIENCE: What happens
is the molecule

is very close to being prolate
or very close to being oblate?
ROBERT FIELD: That's wonderful. AUDIENCE: But not really. How of prolicity or oblicity--

ROBERT FIELD: Well,
I just can't resist. Although this is the subject
of Wednesday's lecture,

I'm going to have to say
some things about this. OK, well first of
all, if the molecule

has a certain minimum
amount of symmetry, you know it's a prolate
or an oblate top.
You know it's a symmetric top. And so if it has a c3 or--
is it the D2 age group?

There's a group that
doesn't have a c3 but it has two
perpendicular c2 axes.

And those are guaranteed
to be symmetric tops. And in the early days of
microwave spectroscopy,

before there were
good computers, people went to great lengths
to synthesize molecules

that were symmetric tops
because they just thought this vector was so beautiful.

Now, suppose we draw
a little diagram-- prolate, oblate.
Now, what do I want to do?
So j is a good quantum number.

No matter what, if
space is isotropic,

total angular
momentum is conserved. So we can draw all
the energy levels
for a given j in both limits.
So let's do j equals 2.

OK, so we have k
equals 0, k equals 1--
and there's two of them-- and k equals 2.
So this is the prolate limit. And so we have here--
we have k equals 0. So that's-- this term is gone.

k equals 1, we get 1a minus
B. And when k equals 2, we get 4a minus B.
And so we have--
and 3a minus b.

OK, over here we have k equals
0, k equals 1, k equals 2.

And now this
pattern is distorted

in the-- this is 1 to 3. But this is small compared
to that because c is small,

a is big. OK, but now-- and
how do we know why--

I mean, k equals 0 is
always singly degenerate. You can't have two of them. Whereas k equals
1, you can have k

equals 1 and k equals
minus 1, and so you can make the plus linear
combination of plus 1

and minus 1, and
the minus linear. So you know there's
going to be pairs. But there's nothing
about the Hamiltonian

that tells you the
difference because, look, you got this quantum
number squared here.

So we know that jkm, you can
have k ranging from plus j

to minus j in steps of one. But there's nothing
about this Hamiltonian

that distinguishes
plus k from minus k. And so this is how we
get-- now what do we do?

We know that there
are no other--

if we go away from the
symmetric top limit, there are no other
good quantum numbers.

And so we draw a
correlation diagram, which
exploits the non-crossing rule.

And this tells us
qualitatively, if I don't draw the
lines too crookedly,

what the energy levels
look like near the oblate and near the prolate
limit, and that there

is a parameter, called the
asymmetry parameter, which goes between plus 1 and minus 1,
which tells you where they are,

where you are
between these limits. AUDIENCE: What is this
magical non-crossing rule

that you invoked?  ROBERT FIELD: If you have two
states of the same symmetry

and you change a parameter
in the Hamiltonian, they can cross
through each other. But recall when we
looked at perturbations

in diatomic molecules, if
we have two states that can perturb each other
because they don't have

a symmetry which corresponds
to an operator, which commutes

with the exact Hamiltonian,
then you get avoided crossings.

And so this
simple-minded diagram,

where this is upside
down and small and this is the right
side up and large,

that's basically all
you need to understand, qualitatively, all
rotational energy levels.

We can do a hell of a lot
better because when we say,

OK, it's not a symmetric top,
there are certain things that don't quite go away
and they're going

to be related to matrix elements
of things like that squared.

And that's what we'll
work out tomorrow. So I apologize for
the fact that I'm not

capable of doing vector analysis
in front of an audience,

at least not today. But we'll be doing quantum
mechanics from here on.
